newsitem.title: INDIA: Cotton - Indian monsoon off to a good start.
newsitem.headline: Cotton - Indian monsoon off to a good start.

text.p: Monsoon rains, most crucial for timely cotton sowing, are off to a good start in India, which has harvested a record crop in 1996/97 (October/September), traders said on Thursday.
They said pre-monsoon rains in May had prompted farmers in India's western state of Gujarat to undertake early sowing.
The four-month June-September monsoon season arrived late by a week but traders said it would not have any adverse impact on the 1997/98 cotton crop.
"As of now, the cotton situation is very satisfactory," said C.H. Mirani, former president of the East India Cotton Association (EICA), a trade representative organisation.
Nearly 70 percent of India's 9.0 million hectares of area under cotton depends on rains for its growth.
Mirani said rains had also arrived in other cotton-growing states where sowing had begun.
"If everything goes well, we may harvest yet another good cotton crop," he said.
EICA has estimated the 1996/97 (October/September) cotton crop at a record 16.78 million bales (one bale is 170 kg), up from 16.27 million in the previous season.
Mirani said cotton prices had already started falling with the arrival of monsoon rains.
Traders said arrival of monsoon rains and demand resistance from yarn mills had capped a recent rally in prices.
In the week to Thursday, spot Gujarat Kalyan fell 300/800 rupees to 14,200/14,300 rupees per candy (355.56 kg). Wagad cotton lost 400/500 rupees to 12,900/13,000 rupees per candy.
Traders estimated unsold cotton stocks in Gujarat at 700,000/800,000 bales.
"Rains have triggered heavy selling by traders and farmers in Gujarat. A setback in the prices of Gujarat cotton has also affected market sentiment in Punjab varieties," one broker said.
Punjab saw-ginned lost 25 rupees to 1,825/1,900 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) and Bengal-deshi fell 10/20 rupees to 1,030/1,070 rupees per maund.
Demand from spinning mills remained low due to sluggish overseas enquiries for Indian cotton yarn, traders said.
"I don't think there's further scope for exports," Mirani said. "Mills also will need cotton till the beginning of the next season."
